reviews.review_msg: Extremely caring, open to feedback, and approachable. But lectures were rambling and didn't really go anywhere. Lectures stopped happening later because the schedule to do presentations involved multiple students presenting on the same reading each week, and we fell way behind schedule. Discussion-based class, but discussions didn't do a ton.
great prof. nice person. actually very sweet. I have taken her course three times in a row. It is her who taught me the importance of language.

She gets all the opposite tags. She is not caring, she doesnt give ANY feedback, she doesnt care about her students. I honestly dont know how she got to teach at SFU! 13 years? She cant even pronounce theories correctly, let alone TEACH. She gets mad when you ask questions, and doesntt give us any guidelines. Slides are useless. WILL UPDATE AT END!

I took courses with this prof twice in a row. Like her testing schemes. SHe does not ask you to memorize but you have to really understand. COme to class and she sometimes will give clue to the possible topics for the final test. fair marker.
great course, nice instructor, very accessible, friendly, fair marker, no memorization but open book test, but you have to come to class to understand the contents. Will take her again

Great course. very enthusiastic instructor. I registered this course to study CDA but actually really like the range of topics covered at class. The test format is really flexible and open. a quite creative instructor. give students freedom to air.

in general a good class, the instructuor is very friendly and accessible. The videos are great! I actually really like linguistic anthropology and want to choose it for a MA  program. But I haven't got a grade yet so far and don't know below someone already said recieve a b-grade. for mid-term, she was very fair.

She is a breath of fresh air in terms of her passion and scholarship. A fair marker. She asks for a lot of dedication at class and active participation but she seems to work hard to help students. I had a lot of respect for this prof. Like the format of the lecture and test. will take her again
I really enjoyed my class with Jie. She is always very helpful and she is a fair marker.

I thought this course is a special topic class but it turned out a breadth course. It should be listed as a breadth course. Jie is so theory driven, I only understand her until she gave examples. Her examples are good and she allowed a lot of discussion at class. In general, good class.

Jie is a great instructor, very enthusiastic about what she taught. A very understanding professor and open to suggestion and discussion. What I like her class is she is not dominating the class and gives students room to talk and ask questions. Bur four hours Monday morning class was too much.
Super enthusiastic about her subject but I find her very difficult to follow during the lecture. It's like she is talking but not really saying anything. Very passionate about her work.

It's obvious she has an accent but she is very competent. Her problems is the concepts she taught are too complicated. she thought students are all third-year students. No. many students in this class has no anthropological background. She doesn't communicate grades via email or anything she already taught at class.

I have to say that students are so hard on this professor, not many people showed up at class. Some students were constantly late, so rude, disturbing to the professor and to the students. I feel so embarrassed. But this is an very interesting course. The materials and perspectives are so fresh.

She is a very fair, easy-going professor. All the exams are open-book, but still a bit hard to cope with. I think students are still not very familiar with linguistic anthropology stuff. One important thing I learned from her is critical discourse analysis. The readings are interesting and engrossing.

I have a quite pleasant experience with this professor. The lectures are organized and quite informative, mixed with video and lively discussions. The strength of this professor is she is very open to suggestions and open to creative, alternative ideas. But four hour lecture is just too long, early Monday morning.
